msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. This manuscript is a quite old exemplar of the corpus. It was written in 1384 during the reign of king Jayasthitimalla (1382-1395). The opening stanza in the Śārdūlavikrīḍita metre is not found in all manuscripts (see for instance Add. 1688 in this collection; cf also Hidas 2012: 100). Both covers are decorated with representations of the five Buddhas of directions and the five goddesses of protection.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.rubric: [1v1] -7- āryamahāpratisarāye || ghorair ityuparogamakarair ākrāntam etaj jagaṃ dṛṣṭvā yakṣapisacarakṣasagaṇaiḥ santrāsitā duḥsahaiḥ sarvvajñena dayovantā tām pratisarān devi[1v2] -1-mutpaditā tām vande paramesvarī bhagavatī sarvvārthasampatkarī ||
msItem.incipit: [1v2] || @ evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān mahāvajramerusikharakūṭāgāre viharati sma || ma|[1v3]hāvajrasamādhibhūmipratiṣṭhāne | mahāvajrakalpavṛkṣasamalaṃkṛ%te |
msItem.finalRubric: [31v1] ||^^^@^^^|| āryamahāpratisarāmahāvidyārajñīrakṣāvidhānakalpo vidyādharasyāyaṃ samāpta[31v2]ptaḥ || ||^^^@^^^|| ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetus teṣān tathāgatā hy avadat teṣā%ñ ca yo nirodha evaṃvādī mhāsramaṇaḥ ||^^^@^^^||
msItem.explicit: [123v1] yānīha bhūtāti samāgatāni sthitāni -5-[123v2]]ntarīkṣe | kurvantu maitrī satataṃ prajāsu divā ca rātrau ca carantu dharmam || % ||^^^@^^^|| -1-tatra buddhānām buddhānubhāvena devatānāñ ca devatānubhāvena mahāti iti upa[123v3]sānteti ||^^^@^^^||
msItem.colophon: [123v3] ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetus teṣān tathāgato hy avadat_ | teṣāñ ca yo nirodha e[123v]vaṃvādī mahāsravaṇaḥ || @ || -1- śreyo 'stu || samvat_ 505 kārtika śukla aṣṭhammyā tithau sanimvaravāsare | śrīśrījayasthitirājamalladevasya vijayarajye likhitaṃ [123v5] vajrācāryamumareṇḍavaṇḍaṇa | śubham astu sarvajagatāṃ ||

supportDesc.foliation: Hooked Nepalākṣara letter-numerals, mid-left margin, verso (1-123).
Nepalākṣara numerals, mid-right margin, verso (1-100, 110-132 [the last 23 folios seem to be wrongly foliated]).
Nepalākṣara numerals, mid-right margin, verso, beneath the second foliation (101-123, corresponding to the foliation in letter-numerals).
supportDesc.condition: Complete, generally in good condition; some modern restorations in the margins. The margins are often very worn out, especially for the first and last folios, but without loss of text except for the very beginning of the manuscript. The text is faded on some folios (see, for instance, 109v).

layout.p: 5-6 lines per page, approximately 65 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: One string hole approximately in the middle of 2 to 2 cm-wide blank space.
layout.p: Each dhāraṇīs starts on a new folio. The puṣpikās are finely drawn in a decorative shape. Some daṇḍas are highlighted with red powder.

handDesc.p: At least two different hands can be identified:

handNote.desc: First hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink (ff. 1v-46r).
Second hand: hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink (ff. 46v-123v).

list.item: On the recto of the second flyleaf at the end of the manuscript, another hand newer-looking but in the same style of character, gives a date (? of recitation) N.S. 572, month Jyeshṭha, in a vernacular [i.e. Newari] (Bendall 1883: 84): oṃ samvat 572 jeṣṭha śuddhi ṭathva puṭhi āṣaralyā khaṣāḍā dina.

bindingDesc.p: On the outer side of the back cover, traces of materials smeared on the manuscript during worship rites.

decoNote.desc:
Both inner covers bear polichrome miniatures.
On the inner side of the front cover, representations of the five Buddhas of directions (Ratnasambhava in yellow; Akṣobhya in blue; Vairocana in white; Amitābha in red; Amoghasiddhi in green).
On the inner side of the back cover, representations of the five goddesses invoked for protection in the text, with colours matching the five Buddhas of directions.

origin.origDate: 505 Nepāla / Saturday, October 22nd, 1384 CE (Petech 1984: 138; see also Additions).

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright on behalf of the Cambridge University Library in 1875.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
